elements.content: The two new metal cyanurates Ba2M­(C3N3O3)2 (M = Sr, Pb) were successfully grown by a solid-state cyclotrimerization reaction. The electronic energy bands of Ba2M­(C3N3O3)2 are totally divergent in spite of their same structures and similar interlayer distances. Theoretical calculations show the narrowing band gap of Ba2Pb­(C3N3O3)2 stems from the strong interaction between Pb 6p orbitals and anti-π orbitals in (C3N3O3)3– groups.

elements.content:
A strong p−π interaction was first discovered in the metal cyanurate Ba2Pb­(C3N3O3)2, which contains heavy Pb metal cations and delocalized (C3N3O3)3− groups.

Inorganic functional optoelectronic materials with specific properties critical for end use have attracted more and more attention owing to their indispensable applications in military and civil fields. They include nonlinear optical (NLO) crystals, birefringent crystals, thermoelectric materials, fluorescence materials, solar cell materials, etc. In view of the structure–property relationship in inorganic compounds, the electronic band structure is an essential parameter, corresponding to several crucial physical parameters such as band gap, effective mass of carriers, and bandwidth, to determine optical responses that contain transition probability, second-order nonlinearity, recombination rate, fluorescence lifetime, etc. Therefore, it is an important and challenging task to modify the band structures to optimize the optical properties of functional materials.

They include nonlinear optical (NLO) crystals, birefringent crystals, thermoelectric materials, fluorescence materials, solar cell materials, etc. In view of the structure-property relationship in inorganic compounds, the electronic band structure is an essential parameter, corresponding to several crucial physical parameters such as band gap, effective mass of carriers, and bandwidth, to determine optical responses that contain transition probability, second-order nonlinearity, recombination rate, fluorescence lifetime, etc. Therefore, it is an important and challenging task to modify the band structures to optimize the optical properties of functional materials.

elements.content: It is well-known that crystal structures and elemental compositions have a strong effect on the shape and region of electronic bands. For instance, aliovalent substitution band engineering was proposed in Pb2GaF2(SeO3)2Cl and Ba2[GaF4(IO3)2]­(IO3) NLO materials. The dominant contribution to the conduction band from d0 transition-metal cations (Ti4+, Nb5+) was removed through substitution by d10 Ga3+ cations. In combination with the introduction of highly electronegative F atoms, their band gap values were dramatically enlarged and the laser damage threshold was also improved. In addition, the structural motif transformation is also an important method for adjusting electronic bands. Inorganic planar π-conjugated anionic groups containing (BO3)3–, (CO3)2–, and (NO3)−  usually possess delocalized π orbitals, exhibiting large linear and nonlinear susceptibility along the structural plane. In particular, the combination of heavy metals (Pb/Bi) and π-conjugated motif is able to bring some unexpected results. For example, the giant nonlinear efficiency in CsPbCO3F (13.5 × KDP) originates from the cooperative enhancement via p−π interactions between Pb2+ and (CO3)2– units. This effect will be further strengthened in Pb2Ba3(BO3)3Cl from double-chelated Pb-BO3 closed systems. Therefore, it has been a hot topic to introduce heavy metals (Pb/Bi/Sn) into inorganic π-conjugated systems to discover unprecedented optical properties.

elements.content: More recently, the (C3N3O3)3– six-membered-ring (6-MR) unit in cyanurates, isoelectronic with the (B3O6)3– group, is a newly developed planar π-conjugated analogue. Meyer et al. reported several metal cyanurates, including Ca3(C3N3O3)2 (CCY), Sr3(C3N3O3)2 (SCY), and R3̅c phase Ba3(C3N3O3)2 (BCY). Subsequently other inorganic cyanurates, K6Cd3(C3N3O3)4, Ba2Mg­(C3N3O3)2 (BMCY), and R3̅ phase Ba3(C3N3O3)2, were found in our center. It is noteworthy that CCY and SCY compounds exhibit much stronger SHG responses in comparison to that of the isostructural analogue β-BBO. A theoretical analysis indicates that the empty pπ orbitals on the B atoms suppress the conjugated interaction in the (B3O3)3– ring, while the (C3N3O3)3– 6-MR enhances conjugation ability due to shorter bond lengths and additional electrons of C atoms.

elements.content: To the best of our knowledge, there are no reports about the introduction of heavy-metal elements into planar metal cyanurate systems. Herein, we report the first Pb-based anhydrous cyanurate, Ba2Pb­(C3N3O3)2 (BPCY), by homovalent substitution of the Ba2 M(C3N3O3)2 (M = divalent alkaline-earth metal) series. The optical properties of BPCY have been measured and analyzed by combining experimental and theoretical investigations. BPCY showed divergent optical response in comparison with the analogues BMCY (M = Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba), although Pb 6s2 lone pair electrons are inert in the structure. The p−π interaction between Pb2+ cations and (C3N3O3)3– anions is highlighted for the first time.

elements.content: Single crystals of Ba2Sr­(C3N3O3)2 (BSCY) and BPCY were grown by high-temperature solid reactions from a mixture of KCNO, SrCl2 or PbCl2, and BaCl2. The polycrystalline samples of BSCY and BPCY were obtained via a solid-state cyclotrimerization reaction with an excess amount of KCNO. The polycrystalline samples are stable in air and sensitive to water (Figure S1). Moreover, both compounds melt congruently at 644 and 575 °C, respectively (Figure S2). Notably, a congruent-melting property is quite favorable for large-size single-crystal growth using the Bridgman–Stockbarger technique.

elements.content: Two cyanurates crystallize in the same trigonal space group of R3̅, and detailed structural information is given in Tables S1–S4. BSCY and BPCY are isostructural, and BPCY is chosen as an example to describe the crystal structure in detail. BPCY features two-dimensional layered structure stacked from the ∞ 2[Pb­(C3N3O3)2]4– double layers. In the structure, the basic anionic group is (C3N3O3)3– 6-MR composed of three linear CNO– units via corner-connected N atoms (a). The bond interdistances of C–O and C–N in the ring are 1.306 and 1.316–1.351 Å, respectively. The C–O/N bond lengths are slightly shorter than the B–O bond in the isoelectronic (B3O6)3– group (e.g., 1.326 and 1.402–1.411 Å in Ba2Mg­(B3O6)2), showing strong conjugated π-bonds. The Pb atom coordinates to six O atoms from the (C3N3O3)3– 6-MR with equal bond distances of 2.659 Å (b,c). Therefore, the Pb2+ cations in the structure are stereochemically inactive. Then the Pb2+ cations are connected with three (C3N3O3)3– groups above and three below to form a ∞ 2[Pb­(C3N3O3)2]4– double layer (d). The interdistance of the double layers is 3.50 Å. The double layers are further stacked into a three-dimensional structure through Ba–O/N bonds with the space between the double layers of 3.13 Å (e). Ba atoms are surrounded by nine O/N atoms with bond distances of 2.746(11)–2.995(14) Å (Figure S3). As shown in Figure S4, Ba2 M(C3N3O3)2 compounds (M = Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba, Pb) are isostructural and exhibit similar double-layered structures. Their structural data for comparison are given in Table S5. Clearly, the lattice constants and interlayer distances are strongly dependent on the radius of M 2+ cations (Figure S4).

elements.content: The gross IR spectroscopy features of BSCY and BPCY (Figure S5) are very similar. There are strong absorption bands ranging from 1500 to 1101 cm–1, and the peaks around 1115, 829, 598, and 471 cm–1 are assigned to the stretching and bending vibrations of the cyanurate 6-MRs. The calculated IR spectra are in good agreement with experimental IR spectra, also confirming the correctness of the structure determination.

elements.content: The absorption edges of BSCY and BPCY are 225 and 264 nm (), corresponding to band gaps of 5.51 and 4.70 eV, respectively. Obviously, the band gap of BPCY was dramatically reduced in comparison with other analogues such as BMCY (5.20 eV), BCCY (5.10 eV), and Ba3(C3N3O3)2 (5.14 eV), thus indicating that the introduction of Pb2+ alters the band structure of metal cyanurates. The ultraviolet photoelectron spectra (UPS) (Figure S6) display similar band spectra of the two compounds, which is consistent with theoretical calculations, implying that the narrowed band gap should be related to conduction bands, but not Pb 6s2 lone pairs in valence bands. This is also in agreement with the simulated charge density maps around Sr2+ and Pb2+ cations with nearly spherical and isotropic electron clouds (Figure S7), suggesting stereochemically inactive 6s2 lone pairs on Pb2+ cations.

elements.content: In order to get deep insight into the band reduction mechanism in BPCY, we performed band structure calculations and molecular orbital analysis for the two metal cyanurates. As shown in , both of them are indirect band gap semiconductors with simulated band gaps of 4.65 and 3.70 eV for BSCY and BPCY, respectively. Their upper valence band regions are basically the same, while the conduction bands are totally different. In early reports on the alkaline-earth-metal cyanurates BMCY and BCCY, the valence band maximum and conduction band minimum are mainly composed of nonbonding N 2p/O 2p electrons and anti-π orbitals on (C3N3O3)3– groups. This case is also similar in BSCY (a). However, the molecular gap of BPCY between nonbonding states and anti-π states is intersected by two intense bands resulting from Pb atoms: namely, Pb 6p orbitals (red bands) and p−π* coexisting orbitals (blue bands) (b). In addition, the density of states also demonstrated that Pb atoms make the dominant contribution to the conduction band bottom (from 3.5 to 5 eV) in BPCY whereas the populations from Sr atoms in BSCY are nearly ignorable (c,d). Particularly, the Pb 6s electrons are strongly localized at the deep valence band (−7.5 eV) and make no contribution to the valence band near the Fermi level, which also indicates that Pb 6s2 lone pairs are stereochemically inert.

elements.content: The visualized conduction bands are plotted in . The lowest conduction bands are composed of Pb 6p orbitals that are strongly deformed from their standard spindle shape (a). The upper conduction bands consist of Pb 6p orbitals and (C3N3O3)3– anti-π orbitals simultaneously, thus suggesting a strong interaction between Pb atoms and adjacent conjugated (C3N3O3)3– groups (b). Notably, these two kinds of orbitals are absent in BSCY, as well as in previously reported BMCY, BCCY and BCY. Moreover, the higher conduction bands are totally contributed by (C3N3O3)3– anti-π orbitals (c), which is as same as for BSCY. Therefore, the narrowed band gap of BPCY is induced by the intercalation of Pb 6p orbitals and strong interaction between Pb 6p and (C3N3O3)3– anti-π-electron configuration.

elements.content: The next question is whether and how this p−π interaction would influence the optical properties of BPCY. Owing to the intercalation of Pb 6p orbitals, the optical transition from valence band to unoccupied conduction band red-shifted. Thus, the dielectric constant and refractive index would also change consequently. We calculated the refractive indices and birefringence of BSCY and BPCY (Figure S8). Their birefringence values at 800 nm are 0.35 and 0.31, which is comparable with previously calculated results in BCCY (0.34), and BCY (0.32). This giant optical anisotropy can be attributed to two main reasons: a strong pπ–pπ conjugated interaction in 6-MR (C3N3O3)3– groups and the aligned planar configuration of (C3N3O3)3– groups. These values are also larger than that of commercial ultraviolet birefringent crystals, such as α-BBO (0.11), and CaCO3 (0.16). In particular, the ordinary n 0 and extraordinary n e values of BPCY significantly increased in comparison with BSCY. This can be also attributed to the enhanced p−π interaction between Pb atoms and (C3N3O3)3– groups, which indeed improve the first-order susceptibility along the principal directions and corresponding refractive indices. Therefore, introducing heavy atoms (Bi3+, Sn2+, Pb2+) in π-conjugated systems should be a general strategy to modulate the optical response, no matter the linear and nonlinear optical properties.

elements.content: In conclusion, we synthesized the two new metal cyanurates BSCY and BPCY. Their crystal structures, thermal stability, vibrational modes, and optical properties were investigated. The first-principles calculations elucidated that it is the p−π distinct interaction between unoccupied Pb 6p orbitals and anti-π orbitals in (C3N3O3)3– groups, but not 6s2 lone pairs, which induced the narrowed band gap in BPCY. Then, the refractive indices and optical anisotropy were also strongly affected. This case not only opens a new pathway to regulate the optical properties in inorganic π-conjugated systems but also provides an attractive platform to design applicable UV birefringent materials.
